title: 111_hr5913
content:
The "Text a Tip Act of 2010" establishes a pilot program for texting crime tips. The Attorney General can provide grants to law enforcement agencies for implementing an anonymous tip program via cell phone text messaging. The funds can be used for developing, expanding, and promoting the program, with the federal share not exceeding 75 percent of the total cost. Grant amounts under this Act must not exceed 75 percent of the program cost and should supplement, not replace, non-Federal funds for activities funded under this Act. Program requirements under this Act must not exceed 75 percent of the program cost and should supplement non-Federal funds. A texting tip program of a State or local law enforcement agency eligible for a grant under this Act must comply with requirements such as administering the program, stripping incoming text messages of identifying information, ensuring texts are untraceable, not replacing existing hotlines, training personnel to respond to tips, making the program compatible with mobile phone providers, and including unidentifiable features. The texting program for law enforcement agencies should include an unidentifiable code for tipsters to provide follow-up information, a feature to abort tips, no additional fees on tipsters' mobile phones, and promotion to encourage citizen participation, especially among youth. To apply for a grant under this Act, a State or local law enforcement agency must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. The application must also include certifications that the program meets the Act's requirements. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for reports and evaluations. SEC. 5. REPORTS AND EVALUATIONS.

Recipients of grants must submit yearly reports to the Attorney General on the effectiveness of activities funded by the grant. The Attorney General, in turn, must submit a yearly report to the Judiciary Committees of the Senate and House of Representatives on the effectiveness of activities under this Act.

SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS.

The term "texting tip program" allows citizens to anonymously text tips to law enforcement agencies to aid in criminal justice by stripping texts of identifying information. "Texting" refers to sending written messages from a mobile phone. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2011 through 2016 to carry out this Act.
